com:
As we traverse the sartorial landscape, meandering through the labyrinthine corridors of high fashion and haute couture, we are inevitably drawn towards the latest and greatest in avant-garde design. And this season, there is one trend that simply cannot be ignored: the beguiling combination of purple and orange, adorned with fishnet accents and emblazoned with argle patterns.

This tantalizing fusion of colors and textures is evocative of the decadent fin-de-siècle salons of Paris, where the bohemian elite gathered to engage in discourse and debate, all the while flaunting their most outlandish and opulent attire. The purple and orange hues harken back to the Fauvist movement of the early 20th century, with its bold and exuberant use of color, while the fishnet accents and argle patterns are reminiscent of the provocative cabaret scene of pre-war Berlin.

But this new line of clothing is more than just a nostalgic nod to the past; it is a statement of modernity and sophistication. The luxurious fabrics and impeccable tailoring make each piece a work of art, fit for the discerning fashionista with a penchant for the avant-garde. Whether it is a flowing purple and orange gown with a fishnet overlay, or a dapper orange blazer with argle-patterned lapels, every garment exudes elegance and refinement.

Of course, such a striking and bold look is not for the faint of heart. But for those who are daring enough to embrace it, the rewards are manifold. Not only will you turn heads and start conversations wherever you go, but you will also be participating in the ongoing conversation about fashion and its role in contemporary culture.

most thrift stores don't have good shit anymore because anywhere that you could actually find decent pieces get ran through by resellers and sold on sites like ebay, depop, etc., at a markup. I'd maybe try scouting out thrift stores in richer areas where people give away good stuff, then trying to get in right when they open; maybe talk to an employee and ask when they restock (not even sure if thrift stores operate that way). If you want good shit for resold prices while not going online go to consignment shops. A common one is Plato's Closet, but there's a few more chains out there and if you live in a city you surely have a few local ones. I've found some of my best clothes at consignment shops for more than they'd be at Goodwill but less than Depop, and the store is filled with clothes that are worth buying essentially.
Either way, I've found a lot of good shit from thrift shops. It's also just something to do when you have nothing to do and don't want to spend too much money, so even if you don't find anything you got out of the house and maybe did a few things you need to do/got something eat. There's no reason to not go on occasion if you like clothing.

last_replies.com:
>>17384426
Chypres are based around a bergamot/hesperidic top notes, resinous mid and oakmossy base, and they smell like your stereotypical mid century "classical" perfume. Examples are stuff like Aromatics Elixir, Chanel PM, most Guerlain shit, Grey Flannel

Fougeres are based on lavender, coumarin, and oakmoss and impart the smell of stuff like shaving foam, talcum powder, sport shower gel, etc. Examples are Skin Bracer, Paco Rabanne pH, Rive Gauche, and later in the 80s they started added a molecule called dihydromyrcenol which is responsible for the stereotypical shower gel scent found in stuff like Green Irish Tweed, Cool Water, and later stuff like Fierce and Sauvage

>>17382371
I'm past 40 and currently undergoing a wardrobe re evaluation, I still have pieces from 10, 20 and even 40 years ago, my rule is I'm gonna wear the until they fall apart before buying new clothes.
I'll tell you what I will avoid in the future.
Larpcore: cargo pants, bombers, biker jackets, milsurp, techware and whatever piece may suggest any longing for lifestyles wich aren't mine.
Military green / black / dark tones: this one isn't so easy because most cheap casual wear come with this color scheme, quality coloured apparel is more expensive, natural tones should be preferred, the texture is also important: natural fibers are richer in tones and depth than synthetic.
Body fitness > fit: no amount of designer clothes will ever do for a well kept body, or if one can't get lean he should embrace gracefully his shape and avoid fits designed for different body types.
That said I still have robes which goes against my points, so I'm gonna use them, when worn out my plan is to slowly transition into Umberto Eco core

I myself try for a slightly modernized '70s flair to my outfits, summer and winter. Here's my method.

>Turtlenecks as often as the weather is feasible
>Denim Sport Shirts
>Patterned shirts/Odd Flannels
>Jingle Jangle Boots/Boots in general
>Trucker Jackets
>Plenty of corduroy
>A westernwear Tan Coat, and unironic Safari Jacket styled Corduroy Coat for winter
>Various oddly patterned Rayon shirts for summer, paired with linen and light wash denim.
>Heavy focus on earth tones throughout my entire wardrobe
>Scents from '70s-early '80s

It's not the focus of my fashion sense, but I always try to come back to it for inspo and twist it to see my needs. I avoid polyester in excess, bell bottoms, and some of the weirder elements of the style though.
